did.unittitle: Elizabeth Feldhusen collection of Brooklyn ephemera
did.abstract: The collection contains ephemera related to Brooklyn, New York, dating from the 1920s to 1992. The collection is especially focused on civic matters of the 1970s and 1980s.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The copyright status of individual items in the collection has not been assessed. Please consult library staff for more information.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: One published report entitled Capital Needs and Priorities for the City of New York (1982) was removed to the library's main book collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains ephemera related to Brooklyn, New York, dating from the 1920s to 1992. The collection is especially focused on civic matters of the 1970s and 1980s. The collection contains material related to the Park Slope Civic Council and the Prospect Park Advisory Committee, including meeting minutes, issues of Civic News, and copies of the Brooklyn Bird Club newsletter The Clapper Rail. Other neighborhoods of Brooklyn, such as Flatbush, are also represented. The collection contains Brooklyn business ephemera dating from the 1930s to 1988. Additionally, it includes cultural ephemera from the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Long Island Historical Society, and various other organizations. Other topics represented in the collection include the Brooklyn Bridge, the Kings County Hospital School of Nursing, politics, the waterfront, and WWII.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: This collection combines two related accessions: S64 and S65.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Elizabeth Feldhusen collection of Brooklyn ephemera, ARC.299, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: An oral history interview with Elizabeth Feldhusen was conducted by the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in 1995 as part of the 131st Evacuation Hospital Nurses oral history collection. It is available online at http://collections.ushmm.org/search/catalog/irn513371.
BHS also houses the Elizabeth Feldhusen records on the Brooklyn Park Advisory Committee (1988.050).
Finally, BHS houses numerous other collections of similiar Brooklyn ephemera.
